questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?

options.option_text: JavaScript is a low level programming language.
The “const” keyword can be used to declare objects with block level scope.
Int, char are some primitive data types in the JavaScript language.
The JavaScript language supports both the first order and higher orderfunctions.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: A web application must implement token based authentication to make theapplication secure.
The JAMStack approach separates out the frontend from the backend, andthey both can be updated/modified independently without affecting the other.
It is recommended to avoid the usage of verbs in the API data URLs.
The idea behind bringing an API is to implement caching.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?

options.option_text: A Celery system can only use Redis as the message broker.
A Celery system may consist of a number of batch jobs.
A Celery system needs worker(s) to execute tasks.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?

options.option_text: The term “polling” generally refers to short polling.
Webhooks are used for 1 way communication, unlike web sockets.
In polling, the connection to the server is kept open, until the data is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?

options.option_text: Cookies are stored on the server.
Cookies are stored on the browser.
Browser sends the cookies to the origin server automatically in general.
Client has to include cookies manually with the request, in general.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?

options.option_text: It is a protocol to allow access to resources, hosted on a different server, onbehalf of a user.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?

options.option_text: Closure is the state of the outer function.
Closure is the state of a variable.
Closure is a function along with its lexical environment or surrounding state.
Closures are created every time a function is created in JavaScript.

question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: The server sent events is a mechanism for a server to push events, and it mustrequire service workers on the client to function properly.
In general, a webhook is meant to pull message(s) from an application.
The usage of a message broker over “point-to-point” communication makesthe application scalable.
There is no difference between webhooks and short polling.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)

options.option_text: The approach 1 will wait for a user input before dispatching the task to thecelery system.
The approach 2 will dispatch the task to the celery system after waiting for 10seconds, and start the execution, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 2 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, butstart the execution after waiting for 10 seconds, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 1 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, andstart the execution, assuming a worker is available.

question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?

options.option_text: In general, an application should have separate Vuex stores for all thecomponents.
A path defined in the routes array in Vue router can consist of a number ofchildren paths.
The wildcard (*) should be put at the top of the routes array in the Vue router,so that it matches with all the paths, which are not implemented.
A Vuex store must be used with all Vue applications.

The value “omit” of “credentials” will force the browser not to send cookies withthe request.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialseven in cross-origin requests.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialsonly for same origin requests.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?

options.option_text: The local storage is a browser based persistent storage.
Cookies are preferred over session or local storage, when the data needs to besent with every request.
The cookies can be set from the server as well as using javascript on the client.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development 2"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **1. Core Topics & Concepts** ### **A. JavaScript Fundamentals** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Primitive Data Types** - JavaScript has **6 primitive types**: `string`, `number`, `boolean`, `null`, `undefined`, `symbol` (and `bigint` in ES2020). - **No `int` or `char`** (unlike Java/C++). 2. **Variable Scoping** - `const`: Block-scoped, cannot be reassigned (but can be mutated if it’s an object/array). - `let`: Block-scoped, can be reassigned. - `var`: Function-scoped (avoid due to hoisting issues). 3. **First-Class & Higher-Order Functions** - **First-class functions**: Treated like any other variable (can be passed as arguments, returned from functions, assigned to variables). - **Higher-order functions**: Functions that take other functions as arguments or return them (e.g., `map`, `filter`, `reduce`). 4. **Closures** - A function + its **lexical environment** (surrounding state). - Created every time a function is defined (not called). - Example: ```javascript function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; } const closure = outer(); // Closure remembers `x`. closure(); // Logs 10. ``` 5. **Arrow Functions & `this` Binding** - Arrow functions **do not bind their own `this`**; they inherit it from the parent scope. - Regular functions bind `this` dynamically (based on how they’re called). 6. **Promises & Async/Await** - **Promise states**: `pending` → `fulfilled` (resolved) or `rejected`. - **Methods**: - `.then()`: Handles resolution. - `.catch()`: Handles rejection. - `.finally()`: Runs regardless of outcome. - **Async/Await**: Syntactic sugar for promises. - `await` pauses execution until the promise settles. - Always wraps in a `try/catch` for error handling. 7. **Logical Operators (`&&`, `||`)** - `||` (OR): Returns the **first truthy value** or the last falsy value. - `&&` (AND): Returns the **first falsy value** or the last truthy value. - Example: ```javascript let a = 2 * 4 || 0 / 4; // 8 (2*4 is truthy) let b = 3 * 4 && 0 / 4; // 0 (0/4 is falsy) ``` --- #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** 1. **Promise Chaining** ```javascript new Promise((resolve, reject) => { if (condition) resolve(value); else reject(error); }) .then(d => console.log("Resolved:", d)) .catch(e => console.log("Rejected:", e)) .finally(() => console.log("Done")); ``` 2. **Async/Await Example** ```javascript async function fetchData() { try { let data = await someAsyncTask(); console.log(data); } catch (err) { console.error(err); } } ``` 3. **Closure Example** ```javascript function createCounter() { let count = 0; return function() { return ++count; }; } const counter = createCounter(); console.log(counter()); // 1 ``` --- ### **B. Web Technologies** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Authentication vs. Authorization** - **OAuth 2.0**: **Authorization** framework (delegates access to resources). - Used for **third-party access** (e.g., "Login with Google"). - **Not for authentication** (though often confused with it). - **Authentication**: Verifying identity (e.g., username/password, JWT). 2. **Tokens & Cookies** - **Cookies**: - Stored in the **browser** (not server). - Sent **automatically** with requests to the same origin. - Used for session management, tracking. - **JWT (JSON Web Tokens)**: - Stateless, signed tokens for authentication. - Typically sent in the `Authorization` header. - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)**: - Attack where a malicious site tricks a user into submitting a request. - **Mitigation**: Anti-CSRF tokens (e.g., Flask’s `{{ csrf_token() }}`). - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - Mechanism to allow/restrict cross-origin requests. - Headers: `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`, `Access-Control-Allow-Credentials`. - **Credentials mode**: - `include`: Send cookies in cross-origin requests. - `omit`: Exclude cookies. - `same-origin`: Default (send only for same origin). 3. **API Design Best Practices** - **RESTful APIs**: - Use **nouns** for endpoints (e.g., `/users`, not `/getUsers`). - Avoid verbs in URLs. - Use **HTTP methods** (`GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`). - **JAMStack**: - **J**avaScript, **A**PIs, **M**arkup. - Decouples frontend (static) from backend (dynamic APIs). - Enables independent scaling. 4. **Webhooks vs. Polling vs. WebSockets** | Feature | Webhooks | Polling (Short/Long) | WebSockets | |------------------|------------------------|---------------------------|---------------------| | **Direction** | Server → Client (1-way)| Client → Server (2-way) | Full-duplex (2-way) | | **Protocol** | HTTP | HTTP | WS/WSS | | **Efficiency** | High (event-driven) | Low (repeated requests) | High | | **Use Case** | GitHub pushes, Stripe | Legacy systems | Chat apps, gaming | 5. **Server-Sent Events (SSE)** - **One-way** communication (server → client). - Uses `EventSource` API. - **Does not require Service Workers** (unlike Web Push). --- #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** 1. **Fetch API with Credentials** ```javascript fetch('https://api.example.com/data', { credentials: 'include' // Send cookies }); ``` 2. **CORS Headers (Server-Side)** ```http Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true ``` 3. **Webhook Example (GitHub)** ```javascript // Server sends POST to client's webhook URL on event (e.g., push). app.post('/webhook', (req, res) => { const payload = req.body; // e.g., GitHub push event // Process payload... }); ``` --- ### **C. Backend & Asynchronous Task Queues** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Celery & Redis** - **Celery**: Distributed task queue for Python. - **Components**: - **Broker** (Redis, RabbitMQ): Manages task queue. - **Worker**: Executes tasks. - **Result Backend** (optional): Stores task results. - **Task Dispatching**: - `task.delay()`: Immediate execution. - `task.apply_async(countdown=10)`: Delayed execution (10 seconds). - **Redis**: In-memory data store used as a broker/result backend. 2. **Message Brokers vs. Point-to-Point** - **Message Broker** (e.g., Redis, RabbitMQ): - Decouples producers/consumers. - Enables **scalability** (multiple workers). - **Point-to-Point**: - Direct communication (e.g., HTTP calls). - **Less scalable** (tight coupling). --- #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** 1. **Celery Task Definition** ```python from celery import Celery app = Celery('tasks', broker='redis://localhost:6379/0') @app.task def send_email(): # Task logic pass # Dispatch immediately send_email.delay() # Dispatch after 10 seconds send_email.apply_async(countdown=10) ``` --- ### **D. Frontend Frameworks (Vue.js)** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Vue.js Fundamentals** - **Reactivity**: Data-driven DOM updates. - **Directives**: - `v-model`: Two-way data binding. - `v-for`: Render lists. - `v-if`/`v-show`: Conditional rendering. - `v-bind`: Bind attributes (e.g., `:class`). - `v-on`: Event handling (e.g., `@click`). - **Lifecycle Hooks**: `created`, `mounted`, `updated`, `destroyed`. 2. **Vue Router** - **Dynamic Routing**: - `path: '/user/:id'` → Matches `/user/123`. - `this.$router.push({ name: 'profile', params: { id: 123 } })`. - **Nested Routes**: Children routes under a parent. - **Wildcard (`*`)**: Catch-all for 404s (should be **last** in routes). 3. **Vuex (State Management)** - **Core Concepts**: - **State**: Single source of truth. - **Getters**: Computed properties for state. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state updates. - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - **Best Practices**: - **Single store** for the entire app (not per component). - Avoid direct state mutations (use mutations/actions). 4. **Component Communication** - **Props**: Parent → Child. - **Events**: Child → Parent (`$emit`). - **Refs**: Direct child access (`this.$refs.child`). - **Provide/Inject**: Deep component hierarchy. 5. **Class & Style Binding** - **Object Syntax**: ```html
``` - **Array Syntax**: ```html
``` 6. **Computed Properties vs. Methods** - **Computed**: Cached, reactive (use for derived data). - **Methods**: Re-run on every render (use for event handlers). 7. **Vue CLI & Single-File Components (SFCs)** - `.vue` files encapsulate `
